passage_text: A polygon, by definition, always has the same number of angles and  sides. Each pair of adjacent sides defines an angle and each pair  of adjacent angles are at the ends of … a side.

A polygon has the same number of angles as sides. Polygons can be classified as either convex or concave. A polygon is convex if no line that contains a side of the polygon contains a point in the interior of the polygon. In a convex polygon, each interior angle measures less than 180 degrees.

Answer by Csanders0. Confidence votes 12.6K. A polygon, by definition, always has the same number of angles and sides. Each pair of adjacent sides defines an angle and each pair of adjacent angles are at the ends of a side.
Does a polygon usually have more sides or angles? Assuming that the polygon is formed from a closed circuit of ray, then the number of ray and the number of angles will be equal.
